case_name: 25 Co-operative Central Banks v. Andhra Pradesh Bank Employees Federation

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2093 and 2094 of 1968 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 2093 and 2094 of 1968. Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated August 5, 1968 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated August 5, 1968 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968. B. Agarwala, K. Srinivasa Murthy, B. P. Singh and Naunit Lal, for the appellants  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Industrial dispute arose between 25 Co-operative Central Banks in Andhra Pradesh and their workmen represented by Andhra Pradesh Bank Employees Federation, Hyderabad.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Bhargava, J. An industrial dispute arose between 25 Co- operative Central Banks in the State of Andhra Pradesh and their workmen represented by the Andhra Pradesh Bank Em- ployees Federation, Hyderabad, which was referred by the Government of Andhra Pradesh to the Industrial Tribunal, Hyderabad, under section 10 1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act No. 14 of 1947.

facts.text: Dispute was referred by Government of Andhra Pradesh to Industrial Tribunal, Hyderabad under section 10(1)(d) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: which was referred by the Government of Andhra Pradesh to the Industrial Tribunal, Hyderabad, under section 10 1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act No. 14 of 1947. The subject-matter of the dispute was divided into three issues.

facts.text: Subject-matter of dispute divided into three issues.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the dispute was divided into three issues. The first issue companyprised a number of service companyditions, viz.,  1  Salary, Scales and Adjustments,  2  Dearness Allowance,

facts.text: First issue comprised 17 service conditions including salary, dearness allowance, leave rules, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The first issue companyprised a number of service companyditions, viz.,  1  Salary, Scales and Adjustments,  2  Dearness Allowance,  3  Special Allowances,  4  other Allowances,  5  Uniforms and Washing Allowances for subordinate staff,  6  Conveyance Charges, Provident Fund and Gratuity,  8  Leave Rules,  9  Joining Time on Transfer,  1  Rules relating to departmental enquiry against employees for misconduct,  11  Probationary Period and Confirmation,  12  Working Hours and Overtime Allowance,  13  Age of Retirement,,  14  Security,  15  Common Good Fund,  16  Service Conditions and  17  Promotions.

facts.text: Second and third issues related to transfers of some employees of Vijayawada Co-operative Central Bank Ltd. and Vizianagaram Co-operative Central Bank Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The second and the third issues both related to the question whether the transfers of some employees of two of the Banks, The Vijayawada Co-operative Central Bank, Ltd., Vijayawada, and The Vizianagaram Co-operative Central Bank Ltd., Vizianagaram, were justified and, if number, to what reliefs were the employees entitled.

facts.text: Banks raised ground before Tribunal that reference invalid due to section 61 of Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act, 1964 excluding Industrial Tribunal jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Industrial Tribunal, one of the grounds raised on behalf of the Banks was that the reference of the disputes to the Tribunal was invalid, because such disputes were required to be referred for decision to the Registrar of the Co-operative Societies under section 61 of the Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act No. 7 of 1964  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and the effect of the provisions of the Act was to exclude the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunals to deal with the same disputes under the Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Tribunal dealt with jurisdiction point as preliminary issue and rejected Banks' contention.

anchor.surface_text: Various other pleas were also taken by the Banks in resisting the claims of the workmen, but, in these appeals, we are number companycerned with them, because the Tribunal dealt with the point, mentioned by us above, as a preliminary issue and rejected the companytention of the Banks.

facts.text: Twenty-four Banks filed Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968 in Andhra Pradesh High Court challenging Tribunal's preliminary decision.

anchor.surface_text: Twenty-four of the Banks thereupon challenged the preliminary decision of the Tribunal on this question, treating it as a preliminary award, by filing two Writ Petitions Nos. 2339 and 2742 of 1968 under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court of Andhra Pradesh.

facts.text: High Court rejected Banks' plea.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the plea of the Banks. These two appeals have been brought up before us by certificate against the orders of the High Court dismissing the two writ petitions.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 2093/1968, appellants are 10 Banks who were petitioners in Writ Petition No. 2339/1968, with 2 petitioner-Banks as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 2093/1968, the appellants are 10 Banks who were petitioners before the High Court in Writ petition No. 2339 of 1968, while 2 of the petitioner-Banks in that writ petition have been impleaded as respondents.

facts.text: In Civil Appeal No. 2094/1968, appellants are 10 Banks from Writ Petition No. 2742/1968, one petitioner-Bank as respondent, another not joined.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal No. 2094 of 1968, the appellants are also 10 Banks who had joined in filing the other Writ Petition No. 2742/1968 in the High Court, while one of the petitioner- Banks in that writ petition has been impleaded as respondent, and another has number joined the appeal as a party.

facts.text: Disputes concern whether Industrial Tribunal jurisdiction barred by s.61 of AP Co-op Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals, therefore, we are only companycerned with one single question as to whether the jurisdiction -of the Industrial Tribunal to adjudicate on the industrial dispute referred to it under s. 10 1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act was barred by the provisions of s. 61 of the Act.

facts.text: Tribunal and High Court held disputes not capable of decision by Registrar under s.61, so reference competent.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, and the High Court, in rejecting the plea taken -on behalf of the Banks, expressed the view that the disputes actually referred to the Tribunal were number capable of being decided by the Registrar of the Co-operative Societies under S. 61 of the Act and, companysequently, the reference to the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act was companypetent.

facts.text: AP Co-operative Societies Act No.7 of 1964 received President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberdoubt true that the Act is an enactment passed by State Legislature which received the assent of the President, so that, if any provision of a Central Act, including the Industrial Disputes Act, is repugnant to any provision of the Act, the provision of the Act will prevail and number the provision of the Central Industrial Disputes Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court interpreted s.61 of Act similar to s.91 of Maharashtra Co-op Societies Act based on Deccan Merchants case.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the similarity between S. 61 of the Act and S. 91  1 of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961, we are of the opinion that the interpretation already placed by this Court on the provisions of S. 91  I  of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961 is fully applicable to the provisions of S. 61 of the Act with which we are companycerned.

facts.text: Dispute on first issue not referable to Registrar as it involves alteration of service conditions beyond Registrar's powers.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests, we have numberdoubt at all that the dispute companyered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal in the present cases companyld number possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act.

facts.text: Conditions of service laid down by bye-laws of Banks.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from them that the companyditions of service of the employees of the Bank have all been laid down by framing special bye-laws. Most of the companyditions of service, which the workmen want to be altered to their benefit, have thus been laid down by the bye-laws,

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's decision that Tribunal has jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the decision of the High Court holding that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to deal with the industrial dispute referred to it must be upheld.

facts.text: Appeals dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: whether the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal to adjudicate on the industrial dispute referred to it under s. 10 1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act was barred by the provisions of s. 61 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals, therefore, we are only concerned with one single question as to whether the jurisdiction -of the Industrial Tribunal to adjudicate on the industrial dispute referred to it under s. 10 1   d  of the Industrial Disputes Act was barred by the provisions of s. 61 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the industrial dispute referred to the Tribunal in the present cases was such as was required to be referred to the Registrar and to be decided by him under section 61 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The general proposition urged that the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act will be barred if the disputes in question can be competently decided by the Registrar under s. 61 of the Act is, therefore, correct and has to be accepted. The question, however, that has to be examined is whether the industrial dispute referred to the Tribunal in the present cases was such as was required to be referred to the Registrar and to be decided by him under section 61 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the dispute covered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal could possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests, we have no doubt at all that the dispute covered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal in the present cases could not possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act.

arguments.claim: The reference of the disputes to the Industrial Tribunal was invalid because such disputes were required to be referred for decision to the Registrar under section 61 of the Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act, excluding the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunals under the Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Industrial Tribunal, one of the grounds raised on behalf of the Banks was that the reference of the disputes to the Tribunal was invalid, because such disputes were required to be referred for decision to the Registrar of the Co-operative Societies under section 61 of the Andhra Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act No. 7 of 1964  hereinafter referred to as the Act , and the effect of the provisions of the Act was to exclude the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunals to deal with the same disputes under the Industrial Disputes Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: General proposition accepted but disputes not covered by s.61 as not touching business narrowly and not capable of resolution by Registrar per Deccan Merchants precedent.

arguments.claim: Disputes actually referred to the Tribunal were not capable of being decided by the Registrar under s.61 of the Act, consequently the reference under Industrial Disputes Act was competent.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, and the High Court, in rejecting the plea taken -on behalf of the Banks, expressed the view that the disputes actually referred to the Tribunal were not capable of being decided by the Registrar of the Co-operative Societies under S. 61 of the Act and, consequently, the reference to the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act was competent.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court upheld High Court's decision that Tribunal had jurisdiction.

arguments.court_reasoning: General proposition correct but not applicable as disputes not covered by s.61.

anchor.surface_text: Further strength is sought in support -of this proposition from the provisions of section 133 of the Act which clearly lays down that the provisions of the Act have overriding effect if there be any provision in any other law inconsistent with the provisions of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Act prevails due to Presidential assent if repugnant.

arguments.claim: Language of s.61 is wide enough to cover disputes between societies and employees as they touch the business of the societies.

anchor.surface_text: Then, it was argued that the language of s. 61 of the Act is wide enough to cover the disputes referred to the Tribunal in these cases, because the disputes are between cooperative societies and their employees and they touch the business of the cooperative societies.

arguments.court_reasoning: 'Touching business' narrowly means trading/commercial activity per Deccan Merchants, excludes service conditions.

arguments.claim: High Court decisions support broad interpretation of 'touching the business of the society' to include employee disputes.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this submission, learned counsel referred us to a number of decisions of various High Courts in which the scope of the provisions contained in s. 61 of the Act or of similar provisions in other local enactments was considered.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to examine in detail due to binding Supreme Court precedent in Deccan Merchants.

arguments.claim: General proposition that Industrial Tribunal jurisdiction barred if disputes competently decidable by Registrar under s.61 is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The general proposition urged that the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act will be barred if the disputes in question can be competently decided by the Registrar under s. 61 of the Act is, therefore, correct and has to be accepted.

arguments.claim: Interpretation of s.91 Maharashtra Act in Deccan Merchants applies to s.61 AP Act: dispute must touch business narrowly (trading activity) and be capable of resolution by Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the similarity between S. 61 of the Act and S. 91 1 of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961, we are of the opinion that the interpretation already placed by this Court on the provisions of S. 91 I of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961 is fully applicable to the provisions of S. 61 of the Act with which we are concerned.

arguments.claim: Dispute on first issue not referable to Registrar under s.61 as involves alteration of service conditions beyond Registrar's powers.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests, we have no doubt at all that the dispute covered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal in the present cases could not possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Bye-laws of co-operative society containing service conditions are law or have force of law, so Industrial Tribunal cannot alter them as contrary to law.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel appearing on behalf of the appellant Banks, however, urged a new point to challenge the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal to deal with the dispute relating to conditions of service to the effect that the conditions of service having been made the subject -matter of bye-laws, an Industrial Tribunal will not be competent to alter them, because even an Industrial Tribunal has no jurisdiction to make orders contrary to law.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s held that a direction made by the Tribunal granting to the workmen more than 12 days sickness or casual leave was illegal. The principle of the deci

arguments.court_reasoning: Bye-laws not law or statutory; bind like contracts, but Tribunals can vary contracts unlike civil courts or Registrar.

arguments.claim: Bye-laws of co-operative society framed under Act do not have force of law.

Ll 2Sup.CI/69-1 5 2 1962 3 S.C.R. 1. 4 1964 T. S.C.R. 234. the Act can be held to be law or to have the force of law.

arguments.claim: Industrial Tribunals have jurisdiction to vary contracts of service unlike Registrar or civil courts.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction which is granted to Industrial Tribunals by the Industrial Disputes Act is not the jurisdiction of merely administering the existing laws and enforcing existing contracts. Industrial Tribunals have the right even to vary contracts of service between the employer and the employees which jurisdiction can never be exercised by a civil court or a Registrar acting under the Co-operative Societies Act,

arguments.claim: Registrar could grant relief under s.16(5) by directing amendment of bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: We may also, in this connection, take notice of the submission made by learned counsel that the Registrar could have granted relief, under S. 16 5 of the Act if he thought that it was advis- able to grant that relief to the workmen.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.16(5) not for deciding s.61 disputes, not for workmen interests but society/co-op movement; not exercisable by delegates/arbitrators.

arguments.claim: Matters covered by issues 2 and 3 could be competently decided by Registrar, so reference incompetent at least for them.
arguments.court_reasoning: Not raised before High Court; no need to decide as competence of entire reference challenged.

holdings.text: The Act is an enactment passed by State Legislature which received the assent of the President, so that, if any provision of a Central Act, including the Industrial Disputes Act, is repugnant to any provision of the Act, the provision of the Act will prevail and not the provision of the Central Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that the Act is an enactment passed by State Legislature which received the assent of the President, so that, if any provision of a Central Act, including the Industrial Disputes Act, is repugnant to any provision of the Act, the provision of the Act will prevail and not the provision of the Central Industrial Disputes Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State Act with Presidential assent prevails over repugnant Central Act per constitutional repugnancy rules.

holdings.text: The general proposition urged that the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act will be barred if the disputes in question can be competently decided by the Registrar under s. 61 of the Act is, therefore, correct and has to be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The general proposition urged that the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act will be barred if the disputes in question can be competently decided by the Registrar under s. 61 of the Act is, therefore, correct and has to be accepted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts general rule of exclusion based on special Act's jurisdiction via non-obstante and overriding provisions.

holdings.text: Considering the similarity between S. 61 of the Act and S. 91 1 of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961, we are of the opinion that the interpretation already placed by this Court on the provisions of S. 91 I of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961 is fully applicable to the provisions of S. 61 of the Act with which we are concerned.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the similarity between S. 61 of the Act and S. 91 1 of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961, we are of the opinion that the interpretation already placed by this Court on the provisions of S. 91 I of the Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961 is fully applicable to the provisions of S. 61 of the Act with which we are concerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Supreme Court precedent from Deccan Merchants interpreting similar provision narrowly.

holdings.text: Applying these tests, we have no doubt at all that the dispute covered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal in the present cases could not possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Applying these tests, we have no doubt at all that the dispute covered by the first issue referred to the Industrial Tribunal in the present cases could not possibly be referred for decision to the Registrar under S. 61 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute does not touch business narrowly (trading activity) and not capable of resolution by Registrar limited to bye-laws.

holdings.text: We are unable to accept the submission that the bye-laws of a cooperative society framed in pursuance of the provisions of the Act can be held to be law or to have the force of law.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the submission that the bye-laws of a cooperative society framed in pursuance of the provisions of  1  1961 II L.L.J. 130  3  1264 II L.L.J. 128. Ll 2Sup.CI/69-1 5  2  1962 3 S.C.R. 1.  4  1964 T. S.C.R. 234. the Act can be held to be law or to have the force of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bye-laws bind like contracts, not statutory; distinguished from rules under statutes.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction which is granted to Industrial Tribunals by the Industrial Disputes Act is not the jurisdiction of merely administering the existing laws and enforcing existing contracts. Industrial Tribunals have the right even to vary contracts of service between the employer and the employees which jurisdiction can never be exercised by a civil court or a Registrar acting under the Co-operative Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction which is granted to Industrial Tribunals by the Industrial Disputes Act is not the jurisdiction of merely administering the existing laws and enforcing existing contracts. Industrial Tribunals have the right even to vary contracts of service between the employer and the employees which jurisdiction can never be exercised by a civil court or a Registrar acting under the Co-operative Societies Act,

holdings.reasoning_summary: ID Act grants power to vary contracts unlike civil courts or Registrar bound by bye-laws.

holdings.text: Consequently, the decision of the High Court holding that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to deal with the industrial dispute referred to it must be upheld.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the decision of the High Court holding that the Tribunal had jurisdiction to deal with the industrial dispute referred to it must be upheld.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above tests to facts; disputes not covered by s.61, so Tribunal jurisdiction intact.

holdings.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Cooperative Milk Societies Union, Ltd. v. State of West Bengal and others 3 , where a dispute as to wages, wage-scales and dearness allowance was held not to be a dispute within the meaning of that word as defined

precedents.case_name: Cooperative Milk Societies Union Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: dispute as to wages, wage-scales and dearness allowance held not a dispute within meaning under Bengal Co-operative Societies Act

precedents.citation: The Deccan Merchants Co- operative Bank Ltd. v. Messrs Dalichand Jugraj Others 4

anchor.surface_text: The Deccan Merchants Co- operative Bank Ltd. v. Messrs Dalichand Jugraj Others 4 . In that case, this Court had to interpret section 91 of the Maharashtra Co-operative Societies Act, 1960  Maharashtra Act 32 of 1961 , the relevant

precedents.case_name: Deccan Merchants Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Dalichand Jugraj
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of 'touching the business of the society' is narrower sense as actual trading or commercial or other similar business activity of the society; disputes must be capable of resolution by Registrar; employee service conditions not part of business
precedents.cited_holding: business has been used in a narrower sense and it means the actual trading or commercial or other similar business activity of the society

anchor.surface_text: Farkhundli v. Potdar 1 . The Court also held - One other limitation on the word dispute may also be placed and that is that the word dispute covers only those disputes which are capable of being resolved by the Registrar

precedents.cited_proposition: interpretation of scope of 'touching' in context of business of society

precedents.citation: the Deccan Merchants Cooperative Bank Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: the Deccan Merchants Cooperative Bank Ltd. 1 , therefore, it must be held that this dispute is not a dispute covered by the provisions of S. 61 of the Act. Such a dispute is not contemplated to be dealt with under s. 62

precedents.case_name: Deccan Merchants Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Dalichand Jugraj
precedents.cited_proposition: disputes not capable of resolution by Registrar under cooperative act are not covered

precedents.citation: South Arcot Co-operative Motor Transport Society, Ltd.  for ex- servicemen  v. Syed Batcha and others 2

anchor.surface_text: South Arcot Co-operative Motor Transport Society, Ltd.  for ex- servicemen  v. Syed Batcha and others 2  where dealing with an industrial claim, the learned Judge held - Therefore, in regard to an industrial claim, like the retrenchment

precedents.case_name: South Arcot Co-operative Motor Transport Society Ltd. v. Syed Batcha
precedents.cited_proposition: Registrar under cooperative act has no jurisdiction over industrial claims like retrenchment compensation; remedy under Industrial Disputes Act
precedents.cited_holding: the authority, acting under it, would have no jurisdiction beyond what the enactment itself conferred on him. He could not, therefore, have jurisdiction to decide a dispute under the Industrial Disputes Act

edges.explanation: h1 addresses Tribunal jurisdiction by holding State Act with Presidential assent prevails over Industrial Disputes Act provisions

anchor.surface_text: It is no doubt true that the Act is an enactment passed by State Legislature which received the assent of the President, so that, if any provision of a Central Act, including the Industrial Disputes Act, is repugnant to any provision of the Act, the provision of the Act will prevail and not the provision of the Central Industrial Disputes Act.
The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The general proposition urged that the jurisdiction of the Industrial Tribunal under the Industrial Disputes Act will be barred if the disputes in question can be competently decided by the Registrar under s. 61 of the Act is, therefore, correct and has to be accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction which is granted to Industrial Tribunals by the Industrial Disputes Act is not the jurisdiction of merely administering the existing laws and enforcing existing contracts. Industrial Tribunals have the right even to vary contracts of service between the employer and the employees which jurisdiction can never be exercised by a civil court or a Registrar acting under the Co-operative Societies Act,
The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.
